subtitle: Helping customers understand their energy journey
cardOverview: Most UK energy companies still rely on emails and letters to communicate switching progress. I designed a self-service tracker that gave Tomato customers real-time visibility into their transfer status—complete with smart vs. traditional meter journeys, proactive error messaging, and enough bouncing tomatoes to make waiting actually pleasant.

storyTeaser.text: No one—not customer service, not backend devs—could explain how the UK energy switching process worked. So I became an amateur backend archaeologist.
storyTeaser.cta: Read how I translated chaos into a customer-facing tracker

contentBlocks.quote: This is really complicated and no one knows the full picture.
contentBlocks.context: That's what the backend team told me when I asked them to explain the UK energy switching process. As a non-UK resident with zero knowledge of the British energy market, I had to piece together a system that even the engineers couldn't fully explain—then make it friendly enough for anxious customers waiting weeks for their switch.

metrics.label: Smart & traditional meter paths with 15+ system states
Replaced unreliable email system with single magic link

blocks.text: When customers switched to Tomato Energy, they entered a weeks-long process with zero visibility. The UK's energy switching system involves multiple parties (old supplier, new supplier, industry database, meter operators) and countless states—but customers only got sporadic email updates.

blocks.html: The real problem? No one at Tomato could actually explain how the full process worked:

items: Customer service couldn't provide a clear outline
Backend engineers each knew their slice but not the bigger picture
No documentation existed
The backend flow diagram was technical jargon that meant nothing to customers
Tomato's email system was unreliable—notifications often failed to send, leaving customers completely in the dark

blocks.text: Customers were left anxious and confused, support was flooded with status queries ("Did you send an email? I didn't get it"), and Tomato had no way to proactively communicate progress reliably.

contentBlocks.heading: From Email Chaos to Self-Service Clarity

before.label: The Old Way
items: Multiple (often failed) email notifications
"Did you get our email?" support tickets
No visibility into delays or bottlenecks
Generic 'processing' messages
Customers completely in the dark

after.label: The New Experience
items: One magic link email to personalised microsite
Real-time backend connection
Clear bottleneck diagnosis (whose fault, why)
Contextual actions for each state
Self-service reduces support burden

blocks.text: One Email, One Link

Bypassed Tomato's unreliable email notification system entirely. Instead of multiple (often failed) emails throughout the journey, customers received one magic link to access their personalised tracking microsite—directly connected to the backend, always up to date.
Clear Status Communication
Translated 15+ technical backend states into four human-readable stages:

items: Application — "We've received your switch request"
Switch Initiation — "Your current supplier has been notified"
Approval — "Good news! Your switch is approved for [date]"
Completion — "Welcome! You're now on Tomato"

blocks.text: Transparent Bottleneck Diagnosis

Designed the interface to clearly show where delays were happening and whose fault they were—empowering customers to self-diagnose issues without calling support. "Your switch is delayed because your previous supplier hasn't approved the transfer" is much more useful than silence or a generic "processing" message.
Smart vs. Traditional Journeys
Built two parallel experiences:

items: Smart meters: Automated reading collection, fewer manual steps
Traditional meters: Clear callouts for when manual readings were required

blocks.text: Error Transparency
Designed clear error messaging for three categories:

items: Application errors: Wrong MPAN, incorrect address, missing information
Switching errors: Debt objections, contract disputes, previous supplier blocking transfer
Technical issues: Meter access problems, database mismatches, system failures

blocks.text: Each error included actionable next steps instead of vague "something went wrong" messages.
Playful Waiting
Added loading animations—tomatoes falling from the top, small bouncing tomato at the bottom of the screen—to keep the brand personality alive during data fetches and make waiting feel less anxious.

contentBlocks.title: Key Learning: Design as Documentation
contentBlocks.insight: The final prototype became the single source of truth for how Tomato's switching process actually worked—something no one at the company could explain before I started.
contentBlocks.result: Referenced by other teams after delivery. Sometimes the best way to get clarity is to start designing and let the process force the right questions.

blocks.text: Created a customer touchpoint that didn't exist before, turning an opaque industry process into something transparent and manageable.
Worked around Tomato's unreliable email infrastructure by designing a single-link solution that gave customers direct backend access—no more "did you get our email?" support tickets.
Reduced customer service burden by letting customers see exactly where bottlenecks were happening and whose responsibility they were, eliminating unnecessary "where's my switch?" queries.

Pieced together a complex system flow that no single person at the company could explain—starting from ground zero as a non-UK resident learning the British energy market—demonstrating resourcefulness in a knowledge-gap environment.
Took scattered brand materials and evolved them into a cohesive, delightful tracking experience that felt unmistakably "Tomato."
Designed for mobile-only launch to get value in customers' hands quickly, proving that strategic constraints can accelerate delivery without sacrificing quality.

Learnings: Engineers know more than they think
